subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: international quikscript
msgSnippet: ... Such a spelling (and some sort of wordlist/dictionary) is also in demand for users of QS who are not native speakers of English. To have to look up words
messageBody:
On 2008-11-03 John Cowan wrote:
> It's already very annoying to publishers to have to put out multiple
> editions of a book in various national spellings: a real break with TO
> would immediately lead to calls for a unified spelling for all
> published
> works (which would then be the one taught in schools, etc.).

Such a spelling (and some sort of wordlist/dictionary) is
also in demand for users of QS who are not native
speakers of English. To have to look up words in a
pronunciation dictionary every so often is quite tedious.

/BP

On 2008-11-03 John Cowan wrote:
> It's already very annoying to publishers to have to put out multiple
> editions of a book in various national spellings: a real break with TO
> would immediately lead to calls for a unified spelling for all 
> published
> works (which would then be the one taught in schools, etc.).

Such a spelling (and some sort of wordlist/dictionary) is
also in demand for users of QS who are not native
speakers of English. To have to look up words in a
pronunciation dictionary every so often is quite tedious.

/BP
